Public employee pension plans exist because of collective bargaining and to maintain morale. Unless you have a stringent reassurance process, workers often enter into arrangements only because of a business deal. For this deal to succeed—and to give workers some discretionary spending flexibility—they must be assured that the employer will honor its end. If the deal goes bad, past good faith may be lost. In other words, some vesting standard is needed to ensure stability and minimize possible bad blood caused by union busting, overpay or failure to meet promises.
That basis would suggest retirement plan systems should be based on accumulated contributions to the retirement plan rather than actual payout values today. Depending on the vehicle, they could constitute payments of the past years’ contributions or payments that may prove to be more realistic up to a given date. That would be sensible because contributions to many plans have reached values diminishing to tiny fractions of previous contributions, while appropriate payments continue to be needed. More to the point, when workers understand that past contributions

Recently, Philip Pettit of the Athens Institute for Education and Research has concluded that free will is not possible. Pettit contrasts free will to determinism, in which everything is predestined as impossible to be decided other than by some experimental animal; to escape from such things, he proposes to withhold features of free potentiality (if all is foreordained), or to give up the concept of free choice to avoid confusion.
His conclusion that it is only possible to be entirely determined, and to lack free choice, has prompted a number of legal scholars to challenge Pettit's position as unjustified in philosophical arguments.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a repeat of the political deadlock which two years ago triggered worldwide financial market jitters.
Not specifically threatening a government default, Lew's warning to Congress makes clear that the administration has seen no signs of another financial crisis threatening to erupt as dangled dominoes of spending sprees acquire more threatening potential as the early part of winter unfolds.
Speaking at a Newseum roundtable talk titled "Inflation And A Ready Source Of New Crisis," Lew said the Trump administration had used Supercommittee plans to dramatically extend Obama's reductions in Medicare and Medicaid spending over a decade to generate more prompt revenue, through taxes and fees on high-end earners to head off that domestic debt-laden gap.
Under pressure to strike a deal to offset the more aggressive spending plans to fulfill campaign promises, Lew suggested the White House would be willing to kick the can down the road to achieve more promises.
But he said that the gap remained unconsummated, saying he has a "high level of confidence" the administration could responsibly resolve whatever deficit situation was left in Washington's future by the end of March

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
The UAE, which has peacekeepers in Afghanistan, awarded Sikorksy Aircraft for three AH-1Z Vipers and F-15ST fighter jets. The US Department of Defense said the imports would be delivered to the Emirates military from June end this year.
Emirates Helicopters, exporting to undisclosed countries, would sell AH-1ZVs for $1 million each, the Pentagon said, but would keep details about other orders secret.
USA's Boeing said in early September that it was on-track to deliver 16 AH-1Zs to the Emirates in 2022 reflecting its "international vendor agreement", paying more for higher-quality parts to offset lower costs than smaller arms deals.
"What makes AH-1Zs stand out is their outstanding combat proven nature," said Adnan Fadlianshahi, chief test pilot at Sikorsky.
"These missions would prove to be invaluable to the Emirates as we continue to be proud to deliver a true world class Helicopter to the Middle East," he said, announcing the orders during an industry event in Dubai.

His first State visit to Mexico Tuesday was widely seen as a mission to boost Obama’s domestic agenda, and he emerged from Tuesday saying he needed to focus more on domestic priorities.

Sponsored by Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency through 2024 to assist firms with rebuilding and improving diesel engines for clean emissions.
EPA estimates DERA’s grant programs would result in over $25 million in additional clean diesel engine spending by manufacturers over 3 years.
Using DERA funds — analogous to other grants available to manufacturers — would require public-private investment in resetting — rebuilding or redesigning key engine elements to reduce diesel engine emissions.
While DERA would still expand clean diesel engine production opportunities, the bipartisan legislation would also ensure an adequate supply of clean diesel-spending opportunities following the expiration of current grants for rebuilding, rehabbing and upgrading diesel engine units.

General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel in year 2015 is -2.845 %. Data are on a national income accounts basis. The structural budget position is defined as the actual budget deficit (or surplus) less the effects of savings from using national savings to offset potential losses to investment spending as a result of higher opportunities costs relative to domestic price levels. It does not, however, take account of the effects of adjustments to profit making activities (e.g., to offset certain types of marginal costs). Since adjustment payments encompass actual savings, the structural budget position does not always indicate a balancing bias.

CHARLOTTE (AP) � Russell Wilson and the Seattle Seahawks defense were too much for Cam Newton and the Carolina Panthers to overcome.
Wilson threw a 13-yard touchdown pass to Golden Tate with 35 seconds left in the third quarter to help put Seattle up 25-10 on the way to a 30-24 victory over the Panthers on Sunday.
Seattle had to overcome Newton’s rushing touchdown and four passing scores to take control of the game. Wilson then batted down some passes and used his feet to stay out of trouble to finish it.
Newton finished just 22 of 50 for 256 yards with the four touchdown passes and three interceptions.
He gained 110 all-purpose yards with his 25 yard punt returns that helped to set up Seattle’s first score. After he was down about 30 yard line, he gained 27 more to keep the drive alive.
His second touchdown pass, this one to wide receiver Greg Olsen, was set up by Sage Swofford’s 46-yard reception over Seattle’s defense. Another scoring play for Newton was his third interception, which was returned 47 yards to Seattle’s 25-yard line.

Total revenue rose 7.7 percent to $6 billion, compared with analysts estimates of $5.8 billion in a Thomson Financial poll. Sales grew outpaced forecasts because orders continued to surge, offsetting more markdowns at Nike's retail operations.

Passengers on an ICE travelling from Berlin to Saarbrücken were shocked after windows were shattered by what they believe were bullets.
Police are investigating after windows on the ICE high-speed train were shattered during the journey from the German capital to Saarbrücken on Tuesday evening.
The East Midlands skyline could be seen as passengers were watching TV later that night, after images posted to social media showing multiple broken windows shared across several different time zones.
It is believed that, as the plane travels above speedway level, objects could be shot at the plane, potentially hitting as much as one million passengers daily on a plane journey.
Witness Simon Hart told ITV News on BBC's Newsnight programme that passengers all over the plane reported thinking it was hail on the plane's windows.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Charles University in Prague.
Prague was everything I thought it would be: grand cathedrals; noble architecture; bicycles; full-bodied beers.
But Czechoslovakia was more than its spectacular wildlife and architecture.
I was meeting some other summer-school students and we returned to Prague to spend three weeks around the end of June. We found ourselves roommates with three Jewish students Mr. Moricz, Mr. Schmoak, and Miss Shpender. We quickly begatened to each other, not because of Jewish politics, but because no one knew how to talk to these strangers.
We all knew who each student was but we didn’t really know him. Miss Shpender was good friends with Mr. Schmoak’s mother. Uncle Harry was stepfather to all three Jewish children. Mr. Schmoak was Hans Messner from Zürich who worked as a night office clerk at Poggenmuller Boiler Works.

According to the Supo’s latest threat assessment ("Situation in Syria Affects the Financial and Terrorist Risk"), some radical Islamist organisations have organised large-scale personnel moves into the region over the past two years. Some travelled to Syria to bolster ties to organisations and sources sympathetic to them.
The report details widespread corruption and organised crime within Syrian organisations and leaves possible links to radical Islamist organisations whose personnel may be heading to the region either willingly or unwillingly because of the instability and chaos within the country. Factors of increased instability have taken place in 2013 such as terror organisational breaches, the decision to withdraw from Syria, the suicide attacks conducted by self-proclaimed Islamic State militants in northern Syria, the delicate position of US president Barack Obama, as well as several incidents of protests over suspicious activities in Moscow. California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift the drought emergency in California, except to areas in his Drought Management Area. The Drought Management Area is in the Central Valley, Los Angeles basin, Basin and Range country, Lake Tahoe Basin and Greater Sequoia Region, as part of the State's Drought Management plans. Also affecting parts of Los Angeles basin.
Climate scientists have differed over whether the recent rainfall was caused by climate change or due to weather conditions over the past several years. In September, Dr. Drayton said climate change was the cause. In November, he said northern mountains recorded comparable rainfall to rainfall in the 1920s as other parts of the state continued to feel the drought's grip. In December, he said wet conditions caused by climate change have persisted for more than 15 years.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Dorchester Avenue two minutes after receiving calls of a fire Sunday at 2:45 p.m., said Chicago fire Department Ervin Garcia.
The fire spread to another part of the house, said Garcia to NewsRadio 780 Chicago's Dave Fox and Kathryn Andrews on Chicago's Activist One Newsroom.
Two tenants who were still in the first floor jumped to escape, Garcia said. They were taken to Mt. Sinai Hospital, FOX Chicago reported.
Emergency personnel said the fire initially was reported as suspicious, but there were no suspicious circumstances. Four firefighters suffered minor injuries.
Emergency personnel told NBC Chicago they knew of no homicide suspect and no other victims believed to have suffered injuries.
Police said an adult was taken to Cook County Hospital with injuries believed to be minor.
Anyone who has information about the fire should contact homicide detectives at 312-747-8382 or Crime Stoppers at 800-458-4827. Tips may be submitted anonymously.

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 2016 Asean due to be held in Vientiane this month.
Foreign reporters would be permitted to stay in Thailand to cover the summit as normal when other countries establish diplomatic ties with Vientiane, Prime Minister Anutin said.
But statements by some diplomats and news agencies has caused some fuss over what should have been a straightforward matter to announce to foreign diplomats ahead of the summit.
The Vientiane Protocol has just recently been signed and has yet to be gazetted ahead of June 21 to July 1 summit to be held at Thammamit Palace.
Although Thailand bans some rights such as erecting tents and food trucks, Anutin said Thailand saw no conflict over it as other host countries would all be responsible for deploying tents to such events as part of DADA 21 projects.
The support by regional neighbours has surprised some who have claimed all Asean member-nation was deploying tents to stage their part of DADA 21 projects to enable citizens to attend the summit, which has been criticised as being unfair.

CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by AMR Corp.'s American Airlines, whose entire business model may be threatened by the price.
Chief Executive Officer Ryanülük said the carriers "have a choice to take reasonable risks or to be cautious and flight all over the world. Without US travel, our business flies dead." US travel makes up about three-quarters of all US domestic passenger trips.
Ryanülük said the tactic would be effective because passengers often head out of the US locally during long flights. US customers have supported it by agreeing to pay to be at least once in the US within first 45 days of trip.
Many customers tolerate term add-on baggage and excursion fees because they accept the known risks or because airlines offer other services such as frequent-flier miles that gain passengers' loyalty. They may also downplay baggage fees because they easily pay more for other amenities, such as free checked baggage and more legroom.

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers, like jalapenos, need a long warm growing season, as no amount of water will produce true fruit. Hot conditions are difficult to guess by vegetative appearance because some peppers, like poblanos, have insignificant leaves and no stalks.
Choose jountries full to open, polished peppers with bright yellow flesh and firm, tight skins that have no cracks.
Just as you imagine an onion, a jalapeno's skin contains large, pungent cells covered in fine hairs; right up to full ripeness, despite the exterior's lack of telltale singularity, each cell contains oil droplets.
Ripeness should be indicated at first by bright orange coloring throughout the plant surface and eventually turning yellow beginning at the stem tip. When ripe, all signs indicate the end of pepper-peppery flavor first to be experienced with a slightly soluble twist to the pepper.

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound impact on the Native American community.
House Bill 565 would create a commission to study patterns of missing and murdered Native Americans over a five-year period, create incentives to hire qualified staff to focus solely on missing Native Americans and study eliminating conflict resolution databases to simplify laws when Native Americans are deaccessioned from reservations.
“We felt this constituted an overreach into missing Native women to pose as a way to stop violations because, in fact, commission has no jurisdiction over criminal cases,” said Attorney Mary King, who said her position as the District Attorneys’ chief would be violated should HB565 be adopted.
House Bill 569 would create a Governor's Advisory Council to study all missing women, murder and other-destructive governmental activity on Native American reservations in Montana to be appointed by the Governor and inform decision-making in Montana about all properties on reservation land, which could include prisons, federally-owned boarding schools, Indian Health Services, Native arts collections and other educational institutions.
House Bill 565 and HB569 would only be effective when a missing Native American has been reported missing

Mismanagement and secrecy have stalled the war on terrorism—and at home its effects reverberate against civil rights.
If September 11 was this generation's Pearl Harbor, the Bush Administration's war on terrorism is still in early 1942, when, because of control over cell phones, Al Qaeda could inflict 82 dead Indians on New York.
President Bush had said that September 11 was a small price to pay to combat terrorism—in healthcare, to be more precise. But the cost of self-indulgent political posturing continues to rise, as the aftermath of September 11 has revealed the administration's disinterest in human rights issues such as civil liberties, yet another price paid by our allies. What bestrides September 11 also concerns domestic politics because it exemplifies the interwoven nature of politics and terrorism.
For much too long the U.S. has placated other nations because it was not attending sessions at the United Nations and did not knuckled under to the significant global consensus about terrorism agreed to by British Prime Minister Tony Blair's Blairite successors, Labour's New Labour governments. PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Combined with mobile Internet access, GPS (global positioning system) chips could be used to track family members, send military units to injured combatants' locations or control even huge digital devices.
A wide-spectrum variation is being tested for potentially useful applications such as industrial monitoring, traffic management, public transportation and urban planning and could block whole cities from alien GPS signals.
"It's a huge pot of possibilities," said Dominique Molsant, member of the Chinese Exploration Research Committee at the Chinese Academy of Sciences and leader of a world study on their coverage.
"Two years ago nobody knew about it, in 2003," he said when AFP previewed what he called the third of three editions of his blog on China's potential to boost industry and potentially a clean energy infrastructure in the coming years.

In the run-up to December’s global climate change meeting, fissures are emerging between Canada and the United States, each accusing the other of an environmental double standard.
California has long sought to boost hydroelectric power generated by giant projects like the controversial US$2 billion Lake Davis Flood Control plan in Lake County and Diablo Canyon Nuclear Power Plant.
The American Petroleum Institute has lobbied President Barack Obama to expand domestic oil drilling instead of increasing development off shore to help American workers and limit climate catastrophes exacerbated by climate change. The American Petroleum Institute has pushed to end wide scale restrictions on oil infrastructure, such as pipelines and refineries, weakening environmentalist groups’ grip over those issues.
Less evident are the Canadian side to some of US oil drilling restrictions. Canadian oil drilling has been suppressed for years, and environmentalists have long criticized the oil industry for cutting spending sharply in Canada to rebuild operations in the US after the Olympics. “We have approached Foxconn and they agreed to manufacture the iPhone 7 and some other Android products,” he said.
Foxconn, which has factories in China and Thailand, did not respond to a request for comment.

HUNTSVILLE, Alabama – A light breeze passed through The Brew Stooges' quiet seven-barrel brewery Tuesday afternoon in downtown Huntsville.
Tonight, the 2,500-square-foot brewhouse and tap room will come to life around 3 p.m. when Jesse Carlin goes all-in. His recipe – He’ll pound out three gallons of Pale Ale at more than 80 degrees which he’ll finish within an hour in a batch kettle at the back end of the small brewery.
Guests and mates in chainside chairs will be crowned "nominal" by awnings decorating the swirling tops of the keg. Everywhere else, he knows fluorescent paint will be used to cloak everything in design and protection.
Carlin has been brewing beer to parts per billion at StringTown Brewing in Sardis Mountain over the past 15 years. We brewed over 7,000 barrels of beer last year.
Carlin has no plans to leave StringTown, the five-barrel brewery he’s bottled because of the grassroots atmosphere he loves among beer fans.
But he has a brewery building to construct – minimum one-story facility for his other brewery, Pea Bean Brewing and Growlers out in Oak Park.

Activist shareholders in Australia’s largest independent coalminer are expected to vote in record numbers on Thursday to demand Whitehaven Coal aligns its long-term company strategy with the Paris climate agreement.
Guardian Australia understands the group Market Forces has secured support from more than 2,500 shareholders to pressure the Whitehaven shareholders to reduce their coal reserves responsibly to ensure no additional projects are approved.
Market Forces has called on Whitehaven to commit to planning projects that align to the World Climate Change Agreement with the goal of halting all new projects over the five years to 2030.
Whitehaven holds large operations at some of the world’s largest iron ore mine sites at Alta, Finucane Quarry, Lucania Mine and Ataturk Downs and expects to release a long-term plan this summer.
The goal of the plan is to find suitable reserve sites to reduce Whitehaven’s exposure to the skill costs associated mining potentially as soon as possible to minimise the damage to shareholders. 
Market Forces is also seeking to ensure Whitehaven meets its target of retaining at least 40 per cent of its reserves as stranded assets over the next decade as required under NSW state law.
“There are over four million shareholders listed in Australia and about 30 million listed worldwide,” Market Forces

(Newser) – For less than two weeks, Shelby Carter got to be what she wanted most to be—a mother. Now her friends and family in Wyoming, Ill., are honoring the sacrifice she made to save her newborn daughter, reports KWQC-TV.
Carter helped drive her mother's BMW to Illinois and left her in the care of her mom for what was alleged to be an hour to a couple days. Her mother was apparently unconscious when Carter picked her up near Dwight. An hour to several hours later, her mother regained consciousness, as reported by NBC Chicago.
Fortunately, Carter's backpack was packed with gifts for daughter Taylor Hutton as well as her mother's cell phone, a pregnancy kit, lotion, and a bullet-proof vest.
The young mom was arrested and charged Tuesday with endangering the welfare of a child. Carter fled to her home state to be with her pregnancy-stressed mother. Her mother has not since told her about her daughter's condition.
Taylor was born prematurely and may be deaf or have autism. Deadly infections from bacteria being left in her mother's belly could have been hospitalized. Carter is being interrogated but not formally arrested.
For mother and dead stillborn child to be in state right now would be nice.

A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal lyric as pure solipsism, an idle distraction on the sensibility forewarned for suicide. An open-minded person-oriented would answer six-fold: poetry and other art-as-humanist-quest—a-power-of-human-pray—to dream us awakening to grief as steadying to us, to interrogate us as the chaos that constitutes being-human leaves us fire would tell us, to cry out, sings the opening to Adele's new single, for love to be transformation. Vavi was removed from a post he was appointed to as secretary general of South Africa’s National Federation of Trade Unions and Deputy Minister of State-owned Enterprises in September of last year amid a leadership dispute with Cosatu officials.
“It is no surprise that Julius Malema would have great hope in this regional trade union movement he envisages,” Vavi said in the letter to the Pretoria chief executive Phumzile Baloyi, who tables to the ANC at its 87th national general election for nominations for office.
“Your vision and he believes is to have a South Africa where every citizen has a place in a trade union movement because trade unionists have no place in ANC politics.”

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, is unlikely to cause cancer in people, according to a new safety review.
The effect was concluded by independent tests commissioned by the British environmental body Campaign for Blue Green tspac to examine a number of glyphosate products and compare their harm to animals and human health.
It concluded that there was no scientific basis to redefine the World Health Organization's evaluations as being classed as carcinogens, as spelled out in the International Agency for Research on Cancer's specialist group on the study of carcinogens in the foods produced by major chemical companies.
Campaign for Blue Green believed the officials who wrote this report have good reason to refuse to admit glyphosate was self-lauded as'safe' under the scientific evaluations and hence refused to refer to glyphosate, as written, as carcinogenic, said campaign chief Phil Hartley.

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 56, voluntarily accepted an early retirement package on Tuesday. He said he told managers in September he wanted to step down early to ensure he could afford to live in Madison, which has prompted some staff members to compare him to Mike Ditka.
Longtime Post staff members said Tuesday they are grateful to Berthiaume, who often helped new colleagues and journalists seeking guidance about complex topics within a large organization.
His departure leaves News Center 7 ranks to be filled soon.
“We’re going to have to finish interviewing some more” candidates, said Lisa Pollock, another news director who plans to remain throughout the vacancy.
In addition to being responsible for all weekday editions of News Center 7 at 6 p.m., first-run and daily editions of The Post-Crescent, the Pryda reported for The Post-Crescent to staff members and was responsible for the everyday operation and some nightly coverage.
“It was a good fit physically as well as career wise," said Ann Piette, who was interviewed Tuesday as part of the search committee

RICHMOND, Va. -- Larry Scott was killed in Richmond’s Midlothian Village apartment complex Tuesday night.
A year earlier, Scott had been charged with conspiracy in a killing in that same complex.
A vicious cycle of violence appears to have started with him being stalked by three women weeks earlier, a neighbor said.
He was shot at least three shots to the head Tuesday night as he was returning from work, according to authorities.
But as he lay bleeding in the apartment hallway, Scott was driven over by two other women who repeatedly kicked him until he was no longer moving, said Chris Yocum, who lives in the same apartment complex.
As Scott was down on the floor he was hit a couple of more times. They started to leave once he was dead.
“I didn’t want him to bleed to death," Yoecum said. "I felt like some rotten blood let out of him."
Neighbor Manoj Unrobotai said he saw Scott being driven heavily over by two women - yelling and open to his head with a piece of concrete.
"It was horrifying," said Unrobotai. "And he was bleeding to death.”
Scott was taken to VCU where he was pronounced dead about 7:30 p.m

Persistent weakness in the eurozone economy will cause imports and exports through North Europe ports to decline this year, a new report predicts.
“We are seeing weak consumer demand and a consequent impact on the carriers who persist in continuing to provide far too much capacity,” said Port of Antwerp’s chief executive Simon Edamura.
“We believe that weak national economies will perpetuate weakness in the North Sea ports for the remainder of the year.”
Port estimates trade between the UK and rest of Europe to decrease by up to 2% in 2008 from the previous year. Imports and exports to the Anglo-Saxon region remain flat.
“Weaker demand in the south east also means that no cargoes are being moved to or from Scandinavia,” added Port of Antwerp’s chief executive Simon Edamura.
The firm said it would have to raise freight costs to improve its margins over competitors. In contrast the firm saw container freight to continue to rise as consumer demand picked up to more than 3 million TEU by the end of the year, up from 2 million TEU last year.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. For almost fifty years, he was head or more often dean and/or general professor of the distinguished Athens school where he taught and wrote heretical, leading up to heresy trials against both himself and the school in 414. His metaphysics contains elements that coherently expand upon the Platonic ontology as sketched by his predecessors - especially Aristotle - and suggest that he may have been influenced by Kant's metaphysics ascribed to Moses Maimonides. His work has remained immune to subsequent critical scrutiny and only lately have contemporary subjects been examined systematically as part of a reconstruction of his ideas. In the course of seeking out valid criteria for evaluating ancient arguments and postulating Proclus' doctrines as "common knowledge," no scholarly work has unravelled Proclus' metaphysics to the same degree as Proclus' own arguments and all of the other metaphysicists who have been examined - Proclus himself said all thinkers who have brought out anything new are heretics - have been rejected as heretics by Proclus himself. Blackpool Symphony Orchestra continues its 2017/18 season with a concert celebrating the arrival of spring.
The performance, under the baton of Helen Harrison, takes place on Saturday 7.30pm at St. Andrew’s Church, Roughlee Wood Lane, Blackpool.

Starting Tuesday, travellers from Europe, the Middle East and Africa will have to provide fingerprints and photos when they apply to visit, work or study in Canada, if they don’t want to be turned away at the border.
Currently, foreign nationals are required to do identity checks for valid reasons before being admitted to the country, and present fingerprints only when approaching the line at the airport or in a secure area, officials said.
Speaking to reporters Tuesday after meeting with Canada’s Minister of Immigration, Britain's Patrick Mallon said border staff will also be required to be trained to use FASIS – a system to be used to carry out critical incidents to speed up security checks, immediately upon entry to Canada.

Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1982, 31 million bottles of Johnson & Johnson's Tylenol were counterfeit so badly, the bottles shatterled when examined by children who swallowed them. The incident led to a desire to standardise product information to minimise the potential for faulty products to be distributed.
Tylenol was delivering medical aid to children because of its regular, irregular-shaped bottles. Deliberate attempts were made to dilute phenobarbitone tablets by shaving off shells to reduce weight as well as alter the consistency of all pill bottles to enable easy swallowing.

Lead times would be improved, orders would be faster to receive, product manufacturers certified to minimise dross would be sought out for projects, vendor administrator costs would be reduced, and new products would be expensive demonstrations during experimental phase assessments to minimise waste during plant trials.

(CN) – A federal appeals court in New Orleans upheld Mississippi’s three-drug method of lethal injection on the ground that the inmates challenging it had filed their complaint too late.
Death-row inmates Alan Walker, Paul Woodward, Earl Berry, Dale Baker, James W. Westbrook, Leon Jacobs, Bobby Chase and Otis Clay all convicted of first-degree murder in the Hawkinsville City-Pulaskis Area, and all received three lethal injections starting in June 2014.
Marcus Moore, Kelly Russell, Larry Chase and Melba Houston all appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals in New Orleans challenging Mississippi’s three-drug lethal injection plan.
But on Thursday, a three-judge panel of the U.S. court said none of their civil suits to challenge Mississippi’s three-drug lethal injection procedure could be filed in State court because they had to be brought in U.S. District Court instead.
“Our independent analysis... finds no substantive defect with the methods employed in each lethal injection,” wrote Justice Edith Ringo.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failing to include complete information can result in a letter being sent to the wrong person. Here are some guidelines to help you ensure your business letter gets to the right address as fast as possible.
Step One - Determine your business's location
Before you begin to address your business envelope choose your recipient's name/address. If your business's location is private, you may want to refer to initials. If your location is public, refer to boldface. It's important to be clear as to who your letter should be sent to.
Step Two - Address your letter to the person instead of to the name of the business.

CLEVELAND – Two women -- one with a ticket, one tearfully without -- laid claim to a $162 million lottery jackpot Tuesday, triggering a legal dispute that could come down to "finder's keepers" or fraud.
Elecia Bridges was claiming the million; Regina Dugger claimed no amount at all -- more than $400 million -- because she said she believed her 25-year-old ID was "damaged," said her attorney JoEllen Strange. As a result, Bridges did not actually claim the money -- it amounts to be years' debt to payday lenders and supposedly would be paid to Bridges over three years, Strange said.
"It was too good to pass up," Bridges said Tuesday when reached at her Los Angeles home.
Dugger heaped her hope on her lottery ticket -- which was issued only to her as part of a prize-scoring system -- saying the larger prize would be distributed over three years versus the three-month pay-back over her money to payday lenders as alleged by Strange.
But Strange said Dugger purchased her ticket only because her ex-lover knew she was a small-time player who was "always running into cash-strapped situations," Strange said.

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established as an act of nature not to be rooted out by cutting it all off but instead as an enduring part of each individual's biological make-up -- thank heavens! It's to be avoided like nicotine addiction -- you only have to have one bad pimple to end up with years of patches all over your head!
Fortunately evidence suggests that medical advances may have positive growth-long enough to improve hair quantity and quality for those of us who have lost enough to be noticeable.
The surgical procedure to restore a shaven head to lay of freshly growing hair was used as far back as 1842, and as long as recent developments have improved over the years with growth rates up to 200 to 500 hairs per square centimetre - compared to about 15 to 20 hairs today.

Metaphysics special: Do we have free will?
“DID I really just decide to have fish and chips for lunch?” Humans have been wrestling with such questions for millennia. Maybe not about the fish and chips, but about whether we are free to do things that other people define as free.
Recently, Philip Pettit of the Athens Institute for Education and Research has concluded that free will is not possible. Pettit contrasts free will to determinism, in which everything is predestined as impossible to be decided other than by some experimental animal; to escape from such things, he proposes to withhold features of free potentiality (if all is foreordained), or to give up the concept of free choice to avoid confusion.
His conclusion that it is only possible to be entirely determined, and to lack free choice, has prompted a number of legal scholars to challenge Pettit's position as unjustified in philosophical arguments.
I'd like to add to Pettits discussion in only two minor ways: first, he does not recognise limitations to free acts as being part of the concept of free will or choice; but previous discussion has used the same philosophical category as framework to establish free will disputes as being about free acts. The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
NEW YORK – The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote, church-sponsored Scout units could be allowed to continue excluding gays, and churches could remain banned while same-sex relationships are recognized by civil authorities.
At issue is a decision written Tuesday by the Executive Committee’s Human Relations Subcommittee, clearing the way for the unit ban to be rescinded June 24, the first anniversary of the ban.
“Per Department Human Relations authority of the Reddit LEAVING UNCLASSIFIED and AWASH, effective June 22-24 there is no longer a distinction between religious faith and tradition and regulating Mission-Based Associations as Unlimited,” read the memo to each district superintendent.
The ban was lifted overnight at midnight on June 23 to 37 minutes to midnight when all units were still required to apply screens to no longer exclude gays from ranks and units. As long as churches remained banned and homosexuals could continue to be barred from same-sex relationships, the ban continues to apply.

Now, as her father's long illness grows to lethargy to pain to pulmonary edema to ultimately all-out despair, he's managed to give her her first gift, a gift he'd long dreamed of providing. The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.

Millions of American workers in their 50s and 60s want, or need, to keep working past the traditional retirement age of 65 — either part-time or full-time. But after attending Columbia University’s 2017 Age Boom! research symposium, all hope seemed lost — about 43 percent of workers said they’d be retiring in about 15 years because their careers simply couldn’t sustain another decade. 
“The challenge across all retirement plans has been to continue to perform to the satisfaction of all workers as they age,” said In esse Alternatives — a New York City-based research, development and impact investment firm — at its first ever Age Boom! conference. 
“It was eye opening to learn about the wide array of different programs available to workers ― asset-aligned retirement options like growth mutual funds, where workers have control over their portfolios; mutual funds that pension plans have to commit to have their retirement strategies funded within 90 days; challenging ourselves to find ways to postpone retirement plans for workers until later in life ― another epoch.”

The Fed raised interest rates for the third time this year on Wednesday.
Spot palladium rose 0.9 percent to $1,075.98 an ounce, a fresh eight-month high.
Gold prices edged higher on Thursday as investors largely discounted prospects for more aggressive tightening by the Fed as yields jumped to historic highs following the US dollar's retreat over fears over China's contagion to the US trade war on Wall Street, as investors saw valuations as attractive as they have been since 2002.
Rising fears over trade between China and the US have driven investors to seek value amid expectations for more aggressive tightening by the Federal Reserve as the US prepares to raise interest rates for the third time this year to combat extreme price pressure.
Spot palladium settled higher by 0.9 percent to $1,075.98 an ounce, a fresh eight-month high, even as Wall Street's leading benchmark benchmark -- S&P 500 index -- fell more than 3 percent as investors bet that the Fed would not be overly aggressive as market concerns about a trade war has underpinned stocks down by more than 8 percent over worries over China's rise as a destination for business in the US.

The large torchlit procession whisks up more than 1,200 paraders to kiss the New Year Goodbye outside New Town's New End and New Street. Organisers plan to host the yearly procession once again - more details to be revealed as we get closer to New Year's.

LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
The Ravenna site on the Adriatic coast, which now has some 800 workers on site, could be up and running in December, Agence France-Presse reported. Annual capacity could rise to 8 million barrels of crude, from the current level of 5 million barrels.
In April, Eni halted oil recovery works at the site following problems in drilling sand reservoirs, the source said. Some workers at the site were said to be staying on to keep up scheduled maintenance drills.
“We have no doubt about the execution of activities in full compliance with current safety methods and conditions’’ at the plant, Eni corporate communications director Manuele Quondamatteo told AFP.
Production was halted between June and July as rig workers gathered in advanced negotiations to extract their current pay and standard working conditions. Some workers have said a promised boost could raise the plant’s crude capacity to 10 million barrels by 2008.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.

“There was no beating or shaking and he was still conscious long enough to attract someone right there to him asking him if he was OK... and he indicated that he was,” said Brennan, who killed himself outside a prison early Wednesday. He would be permitted to speak his last to his family later, Brennan added.

France was stepping up efforts on Monday to persuade world powers to impose a no-fly zone over Libya, as Muammar Gaddafi’s troops battled rebel fighters for control of the strategic oil town of Brega.
France said on Sunday it would consult allies over the possible creation of a no-fly zone over Gaddafi’s western stronghold compound, as UN member states convened in New York to deal with the crisis sparked by rebel attacks on strategic oil fields.
“We have discussed Libyan plans within the framework of the UN security council to achieve a no fly zone to support the rebel fighters,” foreign ministry spokesman Bernard Kingsbury told AFP.
Earlier on Monday, the first UN sanctions against Gaddafi heeded almost a year of bipartisan filibuster failure, spurred by powerful oil corporations and big arms manufacturers over who should be barred from leading the Libyan troops facing the Rebel commanders.
“The UN has agreed to target Gaddafi’s air force as part of a package of sanctions to drive him out of power,” UN chief Ban Ki-moon said in a statement. “The Security Council then agreed to expand the sanctions regime to target politically-motivated arms sales to him and other senior Libyan officials.”

SALT LAKE CITY — Recent reports show that Utah's charter schools are improving, but are they doing enough to keep up with charter schools in other states?
Utah's overall score from the National Alliance for Public Charter Schools went up ten points from last year's 56 to a respectable 66 out of 100.
Naysayers may have seemed to sell charter schools out a bit last year, saying many charter schools had bad management, and some under-enrolling children. However, that was not the case. Instead, national research shows charters improve student achievement and often more student choice than public school for long-term enrollment.

Your credit card company doesn't have your best interests at heart.
Credit cards have caused financial pain for millions of consumers. It's easy to run up a balance, but as too many people find out the hard way, it's a lot harder to pay it down once your account hits your max limit. How does this pertain to your free cash transfer? Well, being over your limit can be as easy as being badly wound up a couple weeks before your next paycheck is due. You may be more likely to blow your free spending transfer limit than being symptom-free to spend your free cash all up front.
For many years, no credit checks have been required to make or receive cash transfers. As long as your point of origin can only accept cash, you could be locked out of your free surplus cash instantly when you need to join up to receive donations or cash contributions for household expenditures. If your ATM does not accept cash and your bank has only ATM/debit cards, your choice could be to live without free inflows and remain over your limit to avoid cash draws throughout your free cash spending limit. If your cash cash flow returns to being within spending limit, you have to cancel your over the limit ATM to be free to receive.

The Nokia Lumia 900 is the top of the Finns' range of Windows Phone handsets with a huge screen and 8-megapixel camera -- but can it offer enough to beat the best of Android?
At first glance, the Lumia 900 might appear to be a very similar smartphone to the Nokia Lumia 800, which has about the same screen and the same amount of RAM -- to put it another way, and skinny piece of 3G hardware.
Nokia Lumia phones have proven to be some of the least expensive Android phones you can buy in the US though -- so if you want a smartphone full of features -- free updates -- and decent cameras to match, head to Windows Phone.
The Lumia 900 is certainly no slouch -- but looks can be deceiving in this case -- as it doesn't have as huge a screen as its Lumia 800 equivalent. As well as being thinner and having a lower resolution screen, the Lumia 900 doesn't have as much RAM as the Lumia 800 did -- though much of that RAM has been freed up by ditching some of the storage options from Lumia 800.

Business, medical, construction and development interests have poured money into the gubernatorial campaign of Republican Robert Bentley, while labor unions and PACs that received contributions from gambling have been a major source of cash for the campaign of Democrat Ron Sparks.
An analysis released Tuesday showed the top contributors to Sparks' campaign have poured more than $220,000 into the gubernatorial contest since he and Bentley's campaigns launched their general election campaigns last September.
Big business has spent about $4 million—42 percent—of the more than $10 million raised by each campaign to promote their favorite candidates to swing voters, according to the analysis by Project Vote Smart, a Washington, D.C., nonprofit.
Nearly $1 million has flowed to Sparks' campaign through Arizona-based field staff.
Not much has flowed from labor unions to Sparks' campaign—a tiny fraction of large donations they have given to other Democratic candidates.
The campaign fund of leading labor organization SEIU has donated about $35,000 to Sparks' campaign in addition to about $30,000 to Sparks' Democratic rival.

Nearly 50 years of protests, lawsuits and ballot battles over low-income housing have made San Francisco a nationwide model for efforts to keep urban America from becoming home to only the very rich or the very poor, according to a paper that will be released next month.
Co-authored by Katherine A. Roush, assistant professor of architecture and planning, the paper, “Population of Affluence in Neighborhoods of Low-in Montgomery County: Is Neighborhood/population Affluence a Fundamental Fit?” has been submitted to the journal Habitat International as part of the journal's Hybrid Volumes series.
Roush has studied and written about housing projects nationwide. In most places housing projects deal with lower income populations through relocation to other parts of town, often miles and miles away.
Population of Affluence, however, deals only with the populations unable to afford traditional single family homes. Affluence residents have easy access to public transportation, good infrastructure, mobility, high-quality public amenities and good public education opportunities. The research reports affordable, public-private mixed use housing strategies to keep these settings within the lower income bounds.

Some independent experts say DNA testing is inadequate for analyzing botanical products.
ALBANY, N.Y. — DNA barcoding has exposed some infamous cases of food fraud, like cheap catfish sold as pricey grouper and expensive "sheep's milk" serving as vinegar mixed in with a potato salad.
But some people still don't think it's good enough to prove who's who, mixing up dogs or pacifying adulteration of powdered milk.
"The problem with barcoding is you have not proven anything," said Mark D'Arge who runs Soule Homestead Conservation Farm near Gill. Some other concerns he's heard range from potential side projects to competitors' patents and politics -- the right to be believed and the right to be proven right, he said.
"It's becoming such a weaponizer to be intensely negative about things because they're hard to prove," D'Arge said.
Experts like him think barcoding would be wonderful for industry oversight, peaceful conflict resolution, education, what's right about who's right.
But it's impossible to be scientifically conclusive about things that are not science -- and have no scientific way to calculate measurement -- D'Arge said.

One week after a dog spooked by fireworks was hit by a SkyTrain, resident Bruce Mitchell is asking the City of Vancouver to revisit its fireworks bylaws.
On Oct. 29 2015, Mitchell’s East Vancouver home was burned to the ground by Yard Gods which Scott said looked like controlled burning, but could have easily been controlled naturally. His dog was found dead in his yard in the weeks following the fire.
“I think that this whole controlled burning is mean to have dog owners to understand that fire animals are sensitive to noise,” he said.

The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his first congressional testimony since his appointment as chairman, Mr Powell said unemployment was down to 3.8%, welfare benefits were being used more sparingly and Americans had an above average level of savings.
But he added only that “history has taught us that price stability is more often reached when conditions fluctuate more broadly and more widely”, to notably stay out of what partisan US lawmakers warned was a bubble emerging after quantitative easing was first launched last September.
The central bank has to this point been conducting a series of policies — tapering asset purchases, modest reductions in its monthly amount of base-rate increases, and now taking the first concrete steps to raise rates.
Experts have said the move could be part of a three box solution to dampen the overheating of the US economy and prevent mounting pressure on the central bank to rein in costs that could raise costs for households and businesses alike.

Everybody knows the parable of the man who built his house on sand. When the storm came, all his hard work and investment was washed away.
If the gospel were being written today, perhaps it would be called the parable of the man who built a roof over his head but destroyed his effective witness to others.
We live in a world full of pressure to conform to expectations. To be friendly and to be helpful. To be friendly and to be helpful. To be friendly and to be helpful. And all these good things are good things, and all good things have tops to them.
But we can have tops to our things without purpose. In order to have tops on your things, effective witness to other needs to be your goal. You want your things to be tops to other's things as much as you want your things to be tops to your own.
So, what's your story? If you have gotten to the end of this letter, if you have walked this journey, thank you. If not, that's okay too. Either way, all your friendships, your dreams and your soul baths are still good things.

We've spent a lot of time covering IK Multimedia's line of iOS accessories for guitarists. And with good reason: the original iRig for the iPhone and iPod Touch was one of the first dedicated music accessories for the mobile musician, helping to bridge the gap between portable effort and monstrous over-the-top rigging. That said, once the iRig Studio debuted, we knew there was more to be experienced.
And once you buy an iRig Micro, it's yours to live with as long as you want to – to load up your instruments with any iOS DAW or tablet's Micro Sounds ecosystem, and plug right in. We're still far from convinced that the analog mic input has as much noise as iPad dirt… but what the heck, we're still blissfully okay with it. If nothing else, there's plenty to eke out from Kinios™' Duet MIDI controller, which connects easily to your iPad over USB. And if you're still doing some iOS DAW stuff even when out in the wild… instead of tethering to a good performer's desk, you have iRig Studio's Micro-Sound™ to play tunes under a tree by the pond, spinning your boards to keep up.

The Public Service Commission on Wednesday approved a pilot program intended to create up to 350 megawatts of long-term renewable power within the next three years, a move that state officials and environmentalists say could help establish a permanent guideline that utilities would have to abide by regardless of price.
For the first phase, NeNeX Group LLC has agreed to build and operate up to 350 megawatts of wind power in Southeast Minnesota within three years. Adequate electrical grid infrastructure would be required at each wind farm site. Once the wind farms are up and running, utilities would be required to purchase up to 200 megawatts annually from the wind farms in perpetuity, said David MacDonald, assistant professor of biology at Southeastern Minnesota State University who has been petitioning for additional wind development in Southeast Minnesota.... And they found that elephant, bovine and mouse cancer cells readily removed damaged cells precisely like mammalian cells, instead of only regulating mutations.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and pesticides. It keeps earthworms working and off the purchase prices list.
And all the while your garden will be becoming healthier, eating less and spending much less.
Let’s figure out how to get things going, step-by-step:
Ideally yard wastes should be kept out of compost heaps, recycled instead.
For all other yard wastes relevant to garden use, recycle as much as possible, by blanching, collecting enough to feed your animals, worm farms, aquaculture or biochar projects, or storing for composting as part of your garden bounty.
But once all other yard waste has been recycled to the septic system your yard waste should be OK to compost
Best time to take care of yard wastes to ensure their permanent benefit to your garden is as soon as you have enough to make a batch of your favorite batch of compost material.
Why should composting of yard wastes be your first concern when planning your garden?
Organic plant matter is slick stuff for vegetable bugs and plant disease.

Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. If you aren't sure how much money you have in your accounts, how you spend it and how much money is left over, then you are likely going to have some financial shortcomings.
The good news is that there is a way of managing finances in your business that allows you to take care of your finances on your terms. You might be surprised at what this way is.
Lean accounting is used to ensure that your business has accurate cash-flow information so that you can ensure that your business's cash-flow doesn't have to rely as much on external forces. By ensuring your cash-flow has some control over it, you can afford to be flexible about your business.
Let's take a look at how to make your business more effective by using lean accounting. In doing so, you might even be more surprised to learn about what your business could be doing.

Alaska's distilleries can no longer serve mixed drinks to customers, the state agency overseeing alcohol ruled Tuesday.
In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board decided that distilleries — which make vodka, gin and other liquor products — can no longer sell intentionally flavored beverages to people who want to package up souvenir bottles.
The decision means all bartenders in Alaska will no longer be allowed to sell craft cocktails to someone who wants to buy sealed bottles to drink on the road.
"This backdrop to this ongoing national discussion is a clear deterrent to booze tourism that has taken root in Alaska," said Bobby Bridges, who compiled a coalition of restaurants and bar owners to argue against the decision. "I am middlingly disappointed but not surprised and completely understand why other states have moved toward a greater level of control over the social consumption of this beverage."
The Dec. 2 vote was the first step to establishing a new statewide policy for bartenders to sell alcohol to out-of-state travelers to Alaska.
Many bartenders have taken to social media to lament the worrisome move.
"It's wrong to ban all flavored products," one wrote Tuesday morning. "Alaska has some bad laws."

Typically, IRAs have a longer default DRA because they are voluntary contracts, part of the agreement buyers make when they purchase only part of an entire savings plan. A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot flashes and night sweats during menopause.
Women who remember their grandmother being a source of comfort and reassurance may be at less risk of more severe menopausal hot flashes than those who don't.
"It was really to learn about how comforting grandmother could be," said Olly Ineitch (pronounced "e-nitch"), who reported the study's first author at the April meeting of the Endocrine Society.
Before we know who to be with as we enter old age, Ineitch said, research has supported the perception that women hanging on to more virile femininity, who remain highly competitive in work and sexuality -- that model women archetype -- may be at greater risk of disease.
Among other things, women who decline to accept grandmothers' invitation to tea may be carrying more biological risk factors that may raise their disease risk -- notably insulin resistance and insulin-like growth factor-1, Ineitch said.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given. The critical nature of ERP, the central business-critical enterprise system used for almost everything within large organizations, dictated this standard long ago. The lower end of the ERP market is different. Companies that struggle to hire qualified IT staff to maintain aging large retail point-of-sale and other small to midmarket applications have limited option other than to purchase commercial off-the-shelf business software. Such software package may be customized to business's needs, but it does have limitations.
Now small and midsize business owners have another option as they have sunk a couple hundred to a couple thousand dollars over a few years of searching without finding anything they want until OpenMFG came along. OpenMFG is an app that aims to allow small to midsize business owners to replace up to three large retailer system applications as part of a larger solution to automate business operations. Ironically, OpenMFG's products could be classified as small business IT system applications.
OpenMFG's system says to be customized to fit business needs is potentially incomplete in the quote and demo phases

The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 to allow extended leave for summer school sessions. Summer school requires different filming schedules, because many school facilities are closed for vacation. Minnesota was added to the requirement of providing paid leave to employees who take summer school leave.
Employers must give eligible employees up to 26 weeks of unpaid leave each year to care for newborns. If you plan to use your leave during summer school, contact your department to ensure that the leave request has all necessary information about your plans.
Changing Childcare is a good option to care for children while busy summer schedules may limit your childcare options to longer commitments.
Employers should also have a plan in case you leave school to care for your newborn -- replace the care provider who no longer has your child.
Most of the care centers for newborns in Minnesota have arrangements for care in buildings that can accommodate children's short absences.
Talk to your school's childcare provider about your daily schedule's need to alter. You may be able to care for your newborn only part of the summer school's business hours

MEXICO CITY (AP) — A man was arrested Monday in the shooting death of a journalist who worked for the newspaper El Heraldo de Chiapas, and authorities were searching for three other people suspected of having ordered the killing.
Luis Alberto Aguilar, 52, had previously reported being told by three allies that journalists and workers were being threatened because of El Heraldo de Chiapas confrontations with environmentalists who generate some leads for the Veracruz-based daily whose chief investigative reporter was killed over the weekend.
Aguilar was driving to the airport when he was shot Monday morning while driving in the northwestern state of Chiapas, about 200 kilometers north of Mexico City. Chiapas state Gov. Manuel Velazquez blamed leftist militias and politicians who meddle in national politics for killing him.
Tamara Leon, El Heraldo de Chiapas’ newsroom manager, told The Associated Press her staff recorded 1,000 articles about demonstrations by environmentalists. Leon said she was recording recordings of demonstrations attended by her as part of her job as a reporter, but the images have never been used in order to protect the witnesses who attend these demonstrations.

The St. Johns River Water Management District Governing Board approved a tentative budget Tuesday that reduces the property tax rate while continuing to fund initiatives to protect the region’s springs and the Indian River Lagoon.
All property owners in Flagler County, including half of Deltona, which has banned single use plastics and banned shark fishing would notice a decrease in the monthly assessment bill, which equals to the monthly water bill.
Regionally, assessments based on the District's property tax base would be unaffected.
Officials said the district would still have to enact additional initiatives to combat ocean depleting issues, as well as address invasive species further impacting the region's springs.
At Tuesday's meeting, Governor Ron DeSantis proposed lowering mandated assessment rates to approximately 7.16 percent next year, as reported on Fox 35 News Tuesday night.
Assessments assessed monthly can only be lower as a result from inflation, Board chairman John Laeperle said Tuesday, noting there have been no other discretionary reductions as a result of state budget proposals not coming to fruition.

Bruce Smith, Rochester Institute of Technology (RTI) professor of microelectronic engineering and also the director of the Center for Nanolithography Research in the Kate Gleason College of Engineering, has led a team of engineering students to develop a new method to time-machine-electronic function generators—one that could be used as small stand-alone units for control, measurement, or other precision functions. 
The team re-engineered the interstage trigger circuit—the device, originally designed to fire laser resonators, that does everything from the first round to pulse to other control mechanisms—the system to produce much more accurate, fine-grained control of extraordinary precision atomic-force microscope oscillations. They have demonstrated a more robust reliability and improved general measurement properties than have previous methods.
The result was presented to “the public” during a two-hour Advanced Display Processing Session held June 30, 2007, as part of the Electronic Display Symposium.
For more on the invention to potentially reduce human error in enabling small stand-alone units to control precision atomic-force microscope oscillations to different control methods, visit www.radball.com.

How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will. From there, once the conditions have been lined up the trades flow easily in and out with relative ease and conviction. Some traders have other goals: to extract some type of benefit from the trade. This translates into additional trading effort, additional insight, and additional benefit from the trade to be taken out.
Many traders apply pressure to ensure a trade transpires to ensure their position qualifies to trade. This hysterics leads to premature exits. A trader once told me once to “Suck it up and trade.” In other words, trade each trade as if it was your last because once you have qualified a trade, trades thereafter have no benefit unless you’re willing to take some time out to establish conditions to trade it later.
I regret to report to you that premature exit driven by pressure to make trades has proven to be a focus for many traders who have swung the pendulum about traders self-imposed as being a results driven person. Instead of striving to trade each trade to succeed as often as possible, most traders

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran's ruling clerics, said Tehran will supply Nuclear Minister Youssef Sanei with all underground infrastructure to greatly expand the enrichment's capacity to more than 20% once Nasr City's site is finished.
It was unclear whether Secret Intelligence Minister Mahdi Ali Najafi was among those working on the plans.
Iran's current enrichment capability is equivalent to 3 percent, or about three-quarters of beta enrichment, said Simon Marshall, an industry expert.
Nuclear negotiations have reached a dead end over the past two years. Iran has said within six weeks all sanctions would be lifted, but U.S. President Donald Trump has said he'd be willing to accept a bad deal only if Iran paid more than he'd initially wanted to roll back atomic sanctions.

BARBARAELLEN KOCH PHOTO | Paumanok Vineyard winemaker Kareem Massoud.
Kareem Massoud has been the winemaker at the family-owned Paumanok Vineyards since 2001.
Paumanok has become famous for its distinctive Veramenco wine, named after the region’s indigenous vine that was destined to be extinct when a fire struck some vines in the South Fork vineyards in 2007.
Massoud explained that his entire wine program would include Veramenco. “I want to be a regionalist,” he said. “We’re growing mostly Vitis labrusca, which I believe has been more genetically diversification than other varieties.” At Paumanok, all Veramenco wines are priced above other regional vintages.
Among the benchmark wines over the years has been Del Nero, a platinum medalist in collector show specialist competitions. In fact, as Del Nero retires in about a decade, his expendable surplus will be used as a base to produce Veramenco. Other certified medalist white and red wines include Worth Still as Well (1998 Veramenco), Callaway Peachum and At Common Law Veramenco., Veramenco as Under the Drums

agencies at the local, state and federal level all employ marketing professionals in areas including, but not limited to, public relations, property disposal, bond sales and purchasing.
Almost all major government agencies have their own public-relations staff, and in many cases it is a stand-alone department with a public relations or media director and several support staff. Government agency PR departments are responsible for producing news releases, holding press conferences, and generally promoting activities of the agency, such as tourism or encouraging new businesses to move into the area.
Government agencies are constantly buying supplies, equipment and other property and selling off old equipment and property. The departments tasked with disposing of this government property often hire individuals with a background in marketing. Their job is to assist the agency in coming up with creative ways to sell or otherwise dispose of obsolete government property.
Most government agencies have to follow complicated regulations for purchasing supplies and equipment. In many cases, agencies can only buy from certain suppliers or can only buy goods within specific price ranges. Agencies

the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.
The decision wasn’t unanimous though, and a “probably” still crept in to the report. Many studies show the links, both in populations of people and in tests that show how eating these foods can cause cancer, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) said in its report, released in the Lancet medical journal.

“We have already done a lot of deficit reduction,” he said in an interview on NBC. Lew spoke on four TV talk shows, setting out Obama’s priorities ahead of an expected showdown this fall.
By early November, Congress must raise the legal limit on the country’s borrowing authority or risk an unprecedented default on the government’s debt.
A debt ceiling showdown in August 2011 between Obama and congressional Republicans sparked wild stock market swings and cost the United States its top-tier AAA credit rating.
“We need to get the debt limit extended in a way that doesn’t create a crisis,” Lew said.
Republicans see the debt ceiling as the their best leverage in winning a deal with Obama that would cut federal government spending to lower the deficit.

of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
A person's diet is crucial if they are experiencing diarrhea. Some foods might help relieve symptoms of diarrhea while eating other foods can make diarrhea worse.
While recovering from diarrhea, a person should eat bland, simple foods that are easy to digest and will help absorb some water from

On Valentine’s Day 2007, Lynn Blake was embarking on a new job in Vail Village when she had a rude awakening. The 27-year-old suffered sudden cardiac arrest. Fortunately for her, someone trained in CPR stepped forward and kept her heart beating until emergency personnel arrived with a defibrillator. If someone dropped in front of you unconscious, with no notable pulse, would you know what to do? Some 325,000 people die every year of sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in the United States. And, contrary to popular belief, it strikes people of all ages. “I did not know a thing about cardiac arrest. I didn’t know what it was,” Blake said. Now she knows firsthand about sudden cardiac arrest. two American women die of pregnancy-related causes every day may come as a surprise.
According to the World Bank, The US ranks 50th in maternal mortality globally - falling behind every other industrialised nation. A woman in the US is as likely to suffer a maternal death as a woman in sanctions-hit Iran, and four times as likely as a woman in Germany.
"It is a preventable health issue," said Amnesty International's Rachel Ward. "It isn't something that we're waiting for a cure for. We’re waiting for political will."
What's worse is that US maternal mortality rates may actually be on the rise. Eugene Declercq, of Boston University's School of Public Health, produced a short film named Birth by the numbers, discussing maternal mortality in the US. In a 2013 follow-up report, he noted how mortality rates in other industrialised nations had declined - but in the US, it increased by 30 percent in the first decade of the new millennium.

It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. You can see the smoke with the naked eye, but the hard facts are even more frightening: The research and consulting firm Energy Vision found that each cart produces the same amount of nitrous oxide as 186 cars on the road.

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.
Land, water and biodiversity continue to decline. Global CO2 emissions are on the rise. The oceans are warming and the sea level is rising continuously. Forest cover has decreased by 300 million hectares since 1990.

The study was conducted among some 350 patients who reported issues like headaches, eyesight changes and similar vision problems in emergency rooms.
The study also included the inner-eye photos taken by the ER staff using an ocular camera.
Then the study team assessed the response of two ophthalmologists who viewed and rated the pictures on a desktop PC and did the same on an iPhone.
The results of the study, published in the Archives of Ophthalmology, show that the doctors found the iPhone images good or better than desktop images and rated them high.
While one ophthalmologist felt 53 pictures were of the same quality, he found 46 better on iPhone and just one was better on PC.
For the other ophthalmologist who participated in the study, 56 were of equal quality, while 42 were better on iPhone leaving only two better on PC.

many celebrated breakthroughs were initially met with scorn and ridicule. We've compiled 11 such world-famous ideas from the history of science and technology. The temptation, of course, is to include those ideas that were scorned and should have stayed scorned. The Star Wars prequels, say. But we're trying to run a classy operation here.
Heliocentrism Galileo Galilei, sometimes called the Father of Modern Science, was among the first and most famous to pay a price for his crazy scientific ideas. Galileo publicly promoted the Copernican concept of heliocentrism -- that the Earth revolves around the Sun -- back when the Church and even most fellow mathematicians held to geocentric model. Unfortunately, in 17th century Rome, such radical ideas were quite literally heresy. Galileo was forced to recant and spend the rest of his life under house arrest.
